Highlights

  • Workday Broadens AI Agent Portfolio Across HR and Finance (Published: 2025-09-16, renewed focus this week)
    Workday expanded its Illuminate™ platform, adding new AI agents for HR, Finance, and vertical-specific needs. These agents now automate high-value, repetitive work such as skills tracking, onboarding, and compliance. This shift positions agentic AI as core to Workday’s offering, not an afterthought. For Deloitte, client demand has matured towards large-scale, production deployments, making AI agent fluency essential for consulting teams who must now address both technical and ethical implementation. The unified approach outpaces fragmented feature sets seen elsewhere.
    More
  • Dayforce Rolls Out AI-Powered Agents for Workflow Acceleration (Published: 2025-12-28)
    Dayforce announced AI agents that automate HR support, answer employee queries, detect payroll anomalies, and dynamically ensure compliance. Initial adoption in healthcare and media signals these agents are succeeding beyond visions, moving into practical domain automation. For consultants, this places higher competitive pressure to benchmark cross-platform agent capabilities, and to guide clients on integrating or choosing among vendors based on real outcomes and extensibility.
    More
  • NIST Publishes New AI Risk Management Guidance, Bolsters Trust in Enterprise AI Agents (Published: 2025-12-29)
    NIST added detailed playbooks to its AI RMF, providing actionable steps for responsible agentic AI rollouts. These new controls target explainability, bias management, and continuous risk assessment—a direct answer to pressure from clients and regulators in HR and finance where automation and fairness must be proven, not assumed. For Deloitte, operationalizing these controls into Workday and broader SaaS engagements is now fundamental to de-risking and winning trust.
    More
  • Deloitte’s AI Data Engineering Suite: Market Enablement for Agentic SaaS (Updated: 2025-12-30)
    Deloitte’s Data Assist™ is now positioned as the connective tissue for agentic automation in cloud HCM/ERP. By shaping data quality, integration, and compliance at the outset, it unlocks the reliability that large Workday and mixed-stack clients require. The alignment with Workday Extend and AI connectors signals a maturing go-to-market for Deloitte, linking technical, governance, and regulatory concerns harmoniously.
    More
  • Research: AI and Fairness in Hiring/HR Now a Board-Level Imperative (Published: 2025-12-28)
    Harvard Business Review highlighted increasing board focus on fairness and explainability in AI-driven hiring, covering tools like Workday and Dayforce. This is shaping a new demand for consulting that combines technical, legal, and operational expertise—less about mere enablement, more about outcome assurance and audit-readiness.
    More
  • Venture/Market Sentiment: VCs Forecast Continued Aggressive Adoption of AI Agents in 2026 (Published: 2025-12-29)
    TechCrunch reports deep enterprise and investor confidence in the agentic AI model—especially for HCM/ERP. This raises the stakes for systems integrators like Deloitte to own the technical and regulatory enablement space, with clear focus on return, compliance, and adoption barriers.
    More

What changed this week

This week, Workday, Dayforce, and several market partners signaled a decisive shift from aspirational AI features toward tangible, agent-driven automation with clear business outcomes. Workday’s agentic roadmap, now reinforced with fresh platform updates, places cognitive workflow automation at the core of its SaaS vision—spanning HR, finance, and compliance. Meanwhile, Dayforce moved aggressively with customer-facing AI agents, forcing the competitive set to focus on agent maturity, verticalization, and real-world adoption metrics over hype.

Externally, NIST published detailed frameworks to regulate the responsible deployment of enterprise AI agents, raising the bar for risk and compliance readiness. In parallel, leading research (HBR) elevated the conversation from enablement to fairness assurance—a trend felt acutely in client and boardroom agendas. Deloitte’s Data Assist™ gains new relevance as an enabler for trustworthy agentic SaaS deployments, bridging data readiness and compliance at scale.

The ecosystem now expects trusted, orchestrated, explainable AI agents—mandating cross-vendor awareness, hands-on enablement, and executive-level assurance for SaaS project success.

Competitive Watch

  • Dayforce
    New AI agents deliver real-time HR, payroll, and compliance support (Dec 28), challenging Workday’s position on workflow automation. Clients will seek vendor-agnostic consulting to compare, integrate, or optimize agent capability. Details
  • ServiceNow
    Expanded thought leadership and documentation on agentic AI and automation orchestration. Establishes ServiceNow’s credibility as an ecosystem orchestrator, influencing decisions on best-fit automation layers. Deloitte must strengthen value in cross-domain journeys. Details
  • SAP
    Strengthening Business Data Cloud with composable, intelligent agent support for S/4HANA. Increases the importance of data architecture in agentic automation success. Details

Enablement

  • Workday AI Agent Development and Customization—See use cases, FAQs, and enablement content at Workday Blog. Outcome: Deploy effective, business-focused agents faster using Workday Extend and Illuminate.
  • NIST AI Risk Management Framework (RMF) Adoption—Access the RMF playbook at NIST.gov. Outcome: Deliver end-to-end responsible agent deployments and compliance assurance.
  • Deloitte Data Assist™ integration best practices—Enable reliable, auditable automation with Deloitte Data Assist™. Outcome: Accelerate client value and de-risk at every phase.

Actions for Next Week

  • Benchmark Workday vs. Dayforce AI agent suites and update client-facing comparative guidance.
  • Pilot NIST AI RMF enablement with existing Workday agent deployments; prepare internal training assets.
  • Embed Data Assist™ practices into in-progress agentic automation projects for stronger data stewardship.
  • Map all major new regulatory and research insights (NIST, HBR) to Deloitte’s Workday project methodology.
  • Advance training and playbook content on orchestrating multi-vendor agent strategies for HCM/ERP/ITSM clients.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Client risk management gaps/fairness blind spots: Consistently anchor implementations in NIST AI RMF; perform routine audits and workshops.
  • Fragmented automation/user experience in multi-SaaS stacks: Promote Deloitte’s expertise in agent orchestration and harmonization.
  • Escalating regulatory/fairness exposure: Embed controls, document decisions, and align all work with NIST & EEOC best practices.

All Sources

  • Workday Illuminate™ Expands with New AI Agents for HR, Finance, and Industry
  • Dayforce Introduces New Dayforce AI Agents to Accelerate How Work Gets Done
  • NIST AI RMF Playbook
  • Deloitte Data Assist™ – AI Data Engineering Solutions
  • New Research on AI and Fairness in Hiring
  • VCs predict strong enterprise AI adoption next year — again
  • The Rise of Agentic AI - Automating the "Un‑automatable"
  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Top AI Agent Examples and Industry Use Cases | Workday

You are “Dan – Workday AI Research Agent.” 
Produce a comprehensive JSON object that matches the schema I will give you exactly.

DATE WINDOW (ET)
- WEEK_START_ET = 2025-12-27
- TODAY_ET = 2026-01-03
- Include items published or updated between these dates.

RESEARCH SCOPE
Analyze developments related to Agentic AI in SaaS ecosystems — with Workday as the anchor — over the past week. 
Include:
- Workday AI advancements, partnerships, and feature releases.
- Competitive moves across major HCM/ERP vendors.
- GSI and boutique consultancy thought leadership, whitepapers, or partnership news.
- Analyst and press coverage (Forrester, Gartner, IDC, Bloomberg, Reuters, etc.).
- Regulatory, governance, or ethical AI considerations impacting enterprise HR systems.
- Patterns across vendor ecosystems and how they reshape client conversations.

WRITING EXPECTATIONS
- Create an **executive-grade synthesis (1200–1500 words)** with deep analysis and contextual insights.
- Each cited source should be summarized in **2–3 paragraphs**, explaining:
  - The essence of the update.
  - The implications for Workday and broader SaaS players.
  - The impact on Deloitte’s Workday practice, offerings, or positioning.
- Include a <h3>“What changed this week”</h3> section synthesizing shifts and sentiment.
- Highlight interconnections among Workday, competitors, GSIs, and boutiques.
- Include quantified insights or examples where possible.
- Do not fabricate; rely strictly on the SOURCE LIST URLs.

FORMATTING RULES
- Return JSON only (no Markdown or prose outside the object).
- `html_body` must use semantic HTML (<h2>, <h3>, <p>, <ul>, <li>, <a href="...">) with absolute URLs.
- Section order: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Limit HTML body to ~45 KB.
- `plain_text_body` = clean text summary with URLs visible.

Return JSON ONLY in this exact shape (no code fences, no extra text):

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1–2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "…", "why_it_matters": "…", "source_url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "…", "implication": "…" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://…", "90_day_outcome": "…" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["…"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "…", "mitigation": "…" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "…", "url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>…</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://…">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2026-01-03.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; STRICTLY restrict to the last 24 hours (from 2026-01-02T08:06 to 2026-01-03T08:06); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000–2500 words; restrict to 2025-12-27…2026-01-03; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://…).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2–3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte’s Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.
Raw OpenAI response JSON

These agents now automate high-value, repetitive work such as skills tracking, onboarding, and compliance. This shift positions agentic AI as core to Workday’s offering, not an afterthought. For Deloitte, client demand has matured towards large-scale, production deployments, making AI agent fluency essential for consulting teams who must now address both technical and ethical implementation. The unified approach outpaces fragmented feature sets seen elsewhere.<br><a href=\\\"https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-09-16-Workday-Illuminate-TM-Expands-with-New-AI-Agents-for-HR,-Finance,-and-Industry\\\">More</a></li><li><strong>Dayforce Rolls Out AI-Powered Agents for Workflow Acceleration (Published: 2025-12-28)</strong><br><a href=\\\"https://www.dayforce.com/who-we-are/newsroom/dayforce-introduces-new-dayforce-ai-agents-to-accelerate-how-work-gets-done\\\">Dayforce</a> announced AI agents that automate HR support, answer employee queries, detect payroll anomalies, and dynamically ensure compliance. Initial adoption in healthcare and media signals these agents are succeeding beyond visions, moving into practical domain automation. For consultants, this places higher competitive pressure to benchmark cross-platform agent capabilities, and to guide clients on integrating or choosing among vendors based on real outcomes and extensibility.<br><a href=\\\"https://www.dayforce.com/who-we-are/newsroom/dayforce-introduces-new-dayforce-ai-agents-to-accelerate-how-work-gets-done\\\">More</a></li><li><strong>NIST Publishes New AI Risk Management Guidance, Bolsters Trust in Enterprise AI Agents (Published: 2025-12-29)</strong><br><a href=\\\"https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/nist-ai-rmf-playbook\\\">NIST</a> added detailed playbooks to its AI RMF, providing actionable steps for responsible agentic AI rollouts. These new controls target explainability, bias management, and continuous risk assessment—a direct answer to pressure from clients and regulators in HR and finance where automation and fairness must be proven, not assumed. For Deloitte, operationalizing these controls into Workday and broader SaaS engagements is now fundamental to de-risking and winning trust.<br><a href=\\\"https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/nist-ai-rmf-playbook\\\">More</a></li><li><strong>Deloitte’s AI Data Engineering Suite: Market Enablement for Agentic SaaS (Updated: 2025-12-30)</strong><br><a href=\\\"https://www.deloitte.com/us/en/services/consulting/services/ai-data-engineering-solutions.html\\\">Deloitte’s Data Assist™</a> is now positioned as the connective tissue for agentic automation in cloud HCM/ERP. By shaping data quality, integration, and compliance at the outset, it unlocks the reliability that large Workday and mixed-stack clients require. The alignment with Workday Extend and AI connectors signals a maturing go-to-market for Deloitte, linking technical, governance, and regulatory concerns harmoniously.<br><a href=\\\"https://www.deloitte.com/us/en/services/consulting/services/ai-data-engineering-solutions.html\\\">More</a></li><li><strong>Research: AI and Fairness in Hiring/HR Now a Board-Level Imperative (Published: 2025-12-28)</strong><br><a href=\\\"https://hbr.org/2025/12/new-research-on-ai-and-fairness-in-hiring\\\">Harvard Business Review</a> highlighted increasing board focus on fairness and explainability in AI-driven hiring, covering tools like Workday and Dayforce. This is shaping a new demand for consulting that combines technical, legal, and operational expertise—less about mere enablement, more about outcome assurance and audit-readiness.<br><a href=\\\"https://hbr.org/2025/12/new-research-on-ai-and-fairness-in-hiring\\\">More</a></li><li><strong>Venture/Market Sentiment: VCs Forecast Continued Aggressive Adoption of AI Agents in 2026 (Published: 2025-12-29)</strong><br><a href=\\\"https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/29/vcs-predict-strong-enterprise-ai-adoption-next-year-again\\\">TechCrunch</a> reports deep enterprise and investor confidence in the agentic AI model—especially for HCM/ERP. This raises the stakes for systems integrators like Deloitte to own the technical and regulatory enablement space, with clear focus on return, compliance, and adoption barriers.<br><a href=\\\"https://techcrunch.com/2025/12/29/vcs-predict-strong-enterprise-ai-adoption-next-year-again\\\">More</a></li></ul><h3>What changed this week</h3><p>This week, Workday, Dayforce, and several market partners signaled a decisive shift from aspirational AI features toward tangible, agent-driven automation with clear business outcomes. Workday’s agentic roadmap, now reinforced with fresh platform updates, places cognitive workflow automation at the core of its SaaS vision—spanning HR, finance, and compliance. Meanwhile, Dayforce moved aggressively with customer-facing AI agents, forcing the competitive set to focus on agent maturity, verticalization, and real-world adoption metrics over hype.</p><p>Externally, NIST published detailed frameworks to regulate the responsible deployment of enterprise AI agents, raising the bar for risk and compliance readiness. In parallel, leading research (HBR) elevated the conversation from enablement to fairness assurance—a trend felt acutely in client and boardroom agendas. Deloitte’s Data Assist™ gains new relevance as an enabler for trustworthy agentic SaaS deployments, bridging data readiness and compliance at scale.</p><p>The ecosystem now expects trusted, orchestrated, explainable AI agents—mandating cross-vendor awareness, hands-on enablement, and executive-level assurance for SaaS project success.</p><h2>Competitive Watch</h2><ul><li><strong>Dayforce</strong><br>New AI agents deliver real-time HR, payroll, and compliance support (Dec 28), challenging Workday’s position on workflow automation. Agent Studio enables organizations to build custom, governed AI agents grounded in trusted metadata from the Agentic Knowledge Layer.       "content": "“There are likely to be many documents or data sets in a company that don’t have permissions correctly locked down,” he says, in the company’s 2026 AI predictions. “If you feed that into generative or agentic AI, the tool may expose data that it shouldn’t.”\n\nIt's not just internal productivity at stake either, according to Saleforce. It is each company's image and reputation in the marketplace, predicts Adam Evans, EVP & GM, Salesforce AI. [...] Ramsey urged companies to start small and look for the task that is “bleeding time and money,” then fix it end-to-end with AI. But to make that effective, he turned the conversation back to governance.\n\n“You need one entry point with clear policies and approvals,” he said. “A secure foundation for your AI is how you turn an isolated win into a repeatable pattern that scales across your business.” [...] In terms of governing AI agents, Snowflake CISO Brad Jones says the job in front of his counterparts is to walk the line between putting up guardrails around their behavior while leaving room for operators to experiment and innovate, which is a job for data governance.",

      "title": "一文读懂：大模型RAG（检索增强生成）含高级方法",
      "url": "https://www.zhihu.com/tardis/zm/art/675509396",
      "content": "提供多样化的上下文：因为你可以从不同的角度查看用户的查询，所以顶级结果里会出现更多样化的内容片段。与专注于单一视角的内容段落相比，你更有可能看到能够涵盖话题多个方面的内容作为顶级结果出现。\n   额外的控制层面：像其他机器学习解决方案一样，RAG融合提供了额外的控制手柄，让你可以微调你的应用，并让它更加符合你的期望目标。\n   自动校正：通过使用LLM作为用户在文本框中输入内容与实际在数据库中搜索内容之间的中间人，你可以纠正拼写错误，添加与用户查询相关的上下文信息（关于用户的信息、时间、他们的账户状态等），以及/或潜在地筛选特定类型的内容。 [...] ### 缺点：\n\n   延迟:正如你现在可能知道的，LLMs需要大量的计算资源，因此它们的速度相对较慢(相对于应用程序中的其他部分)。根据你的应用程序，向LLM发送一次额外的请求可能会让用户的体验变得糟糕，因为他们可能需要等待几百毫秒的时间。\n   自动纠错:是的，这是一个优点，但是当它不起作用时，也可能是一个缺点。这通常发生在你的内容包含内部术语或行话，而这些术语或行话没有出现在LLM学习过的数据中。在这种情况下，LLM可能会出现困惑并生成完全无关的查询，从而影响到最后的结果。\n   成本:正如之前讨论的，如果RAG融合对你应用程序的整体效益贡献不大，你最终可能会花费更多的费用，但收益却很有限。\n\n有了以上的介绍，接下来讨论一下在什么情况下最有可能通过实现RAG融合得到好的效果。如果你的应用程序的内容主要基于常见概念，那么你更有可能从使用RAG融合中获益良多。\n\nImage 20\n\n### RAG融合n不适用场景 [...] 数据向量化后构建索引，并写入数据库的过程可以概述为数据入库过程，适用于RAG场景的数据库包括：FAISS、Chromadb、ES、milvus等。一般可以根据业务场景、硬件、性能需求等多因素综合考虑，选择合适的数据库。\n\nImage 7\n\n### 应用阶段：\n\n在应用阶段，可以根据用户的提问，通过高效的检索方法，召回与提问最相关的知识，并融入Prompt；大模型参考当前提问和相关知识，生成相应的答案。关键环节包括：数据检索、注入Prompt等。\n\nImage 8\n\n数据检索\n\n   数据检索\n\n常见的数据检索方法包括：相似性检索、全文检索等，根据检索效果，一般可以选择多种检索方式融合，提升召回率。\n\n       相似性检索：即计算查询向量与所有存储向量的相似性得分，返回得分高的记录。常见的相似性计算方法包括：余弦相似性、欧氏距离、曼哈顿距离等。\n       全文检索：全文检索是一种比较经典的检索方式，在数据存入时，通过关键词构建倒排索引；在检索时，通过关键词进行全文检索，找到对应的记录。\n\n   注入Prompt\n\nImage 9\n\nLLM生成",
      "score": 0.20472358,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "title": "大家都在做rag，那么如何评价rag的质量呢? - 知乎",
      "url": "https://www.zhihu.com/question/1914466302451495286",
      "content": "3. 跨模态融合（Cross-modal Fusion）：为应对真实世界信息的多样性，数据集开始融合文本、图像、表格等多种数据模态。这些数据集（如`WebQA`, `MultimodalQA`）要求模型具备跨模态理解与推理的能力，推动了RAG技术向更复杂的认知智能方向发展。 [...] 评估基准数据集在RAG生态中扮演着“裁判员”和“指挥棒”的关键角色。与面向特定应用的任务数据集不同，这类数据集的核心目标是系统性地、多维度地、细粒度地剖析RAG系统的内在能力与缺陷。它们的重要性在于为快速发展的RAG研究提供一个公平、可复现的竞技场，使得不同的模型、检索器、生成器或融合策略可以在统一的标准下进行横向比较。通过精心设计的测试用例，这些基准不仅衡量系统的最终表现，更深入地探究其在特定压力下的行为，如处理噪声、拒绝回答、整合信息和对抗事实谬误等。这推动了RAG技术从单纯追求更高分数，转向构建更鲁棒、更可信、更智能的系统。 [...] 即日至 2026 年 1 月 10 日，晒猫角逐知乎「猫王」桂冠，就有机会参与瓜分 20 万盐粒和限定活动徽章挂件。\n\n查看详情\n\n知乎的广告\n\n查看剩余 9 条回答\n\n（为什么？）\n\n下载知乎客户端\n\n与世界分享知识、经验和见解\n\n广告\n\n相关问题\n\n为什么现在RAG这么火? 5 个回答\n\n为什么有人认为RAG没有未来？ 4 个回答\n\n如何透彻理解rag？ 60 个回答\n\n看了披荆斩棘的哥哥说唱组为啥感觉没一个正常人? 1 个回答\n\n大家都在搜\n\n换一换\n\n我的摸鱼图鉴\n426 万\n热\n\n韩国总统李在明将访华\n425 万\n新\n\n美国斩杀线是什么\n423 万\n热\n\n东部战区开展正义使命-2025演习\n377 万\n热\n\n解放军无人机俯瞰台北101\n366 万\n热\n\n林俊杰官宣恋情\n339 万\n热\n\n东部战区组织实弹射击\n331 万\n热\n\n2025 年度知友辟谣榜\n328 万\n\n中柬泰三方抚仙会晤新闻公报发布\n326 万\n\n霸王茶姬咖啡因含量遭质疑\n318 万\n热\n\n广告\n\n想来知乎工作？请发送邮件到 jobs@zhihu.com",

      "content": "二、论文思路 定义：MM-RAG是一种将大型语言模型（如GPT-3）与使用对比学习嵌入的多模态检索器相结合的技术。 多模态嵌入空间：将不同格式的数据（图片、音频、视频、文本）编码到同一语义嵌入空间中，使得可以通过嵌入相似性进行跨模态搜索。",

      "content": "然而用户的实际需求和数据是多样的，导致通用RAG在实践中仍面临多重挑战，如检索信息缺失、复杂PDF解析困难、无法提取特定内容、格式处理不佳、统计类问答能力缺失等。 这些问题削弱了RAG在实际场景中的精度与可信度，亟需通过技术创新与优化进行解决。中国联通发挥其丰富业务场景和广泛",

    {
      "title": "02-大模型中的RAG流程及问题 - 知乎",
      "url": "https://www.zhihu.com/tardis/zm/art/717438258",
      "content": "2. 增强：将检索到的信息用作生成模型（即大语言模型）的上下文输入，以增强模型对特定问题的理解和回答能力。这一步的目的是将外部知识融入生成过程中，使生成的文本内容更加丰富、准确和符合用户需求。\n\n3. 生成：结合LLM生成符合用户需求的回答。生成器会利用检索到的信息作为上下文输入，并结合大语言模型来生成文本内容。\n\n## 三、RAG流程及问题分析\n\n### （1）文档导入\n\n在该阶段要把使用到的文档都进行导入。由于文档涉及多种格式，比如常见的有：WORD、PDF、PPT、Excel、TXT、Markdown等，格式不同，处理的方式也不同。因此，如何读取和处理文档是文档导入阶段需要做好考虑。\n\n### （2）文档标注\n\n在导入文档后，我们需要将文档分割并标注成一系列的片段（chunks）。如果分块过大，可能会混入过多无关信息，从而降低检索的准确性和效率。反之，如果分块过小，则可能导致丢失重要的上下文信息，使得生成的回答缺乏连贯性和深度。\n\n为了平衡这一点，选择合适的分块大小至关重要，既要确保每个片段足够小以便于管理，又要保证足够的上下文以维持信息的连贯性和完整性。 [...] 在用户提问环节，若问题显得过于简单或表达不够明确，这些因素均可能削弱大模型的最终表现效果。为了更精准地捕捉用户的真实意图，我们在问题处理阶段会采取优化与重写的策略，对用户的提问进行精细调整。\n\n### （5） 向量检索\n\n系统需要将用户提出的问题转化为向量形式，然后在向量数据库中进行检索。这一过程中，同样存在着多种不同的检索技术方案可供选择。常用的检索算法包括基于距离的检索（如欧氏距离、余弦相似度等）和基于近似最近邻（ANN）的检索算法（如LSH、HNSW、IVF等）。\n\n### （6） Reranking\n\n在处理检索结果时，我们并不直接将初始检索结果呈现给用户，而是采用Reranking（重排模型）步骤对检索结果进行精细化处理。\n\n重排模型通过深度分析初始检索列表中的各项内容，实施更为细致的相关性评估和重新排序，旨在精准捕捉用户查询背后的真实意图与期望。 [...] Document Embedding是将整篇文档转换为一个向量。在文档检索、文档分类等任务中，Document Embedding能够捕捉文档的整体语义信息。类似于Sentence Embedding，但可能需要考虑文档的更长范围和更复杂结构。\n\n4. Contextual Embedding（上下文嵌入）\n\nContextual Embedding考虑了单词或句子在特定上下文中的意义。在需要理解语言上下文的场景中，如机器翻译、对话系统等，Contextual Embedding能够提供更加准确和丰富的语义信息。基于Transformer的模型（如BERT）是实现Contextual Embedding的典型代表。\n\n5. Custom Embedding（自定义嵌入）\n\n根据特定任务和数据集训练的Embedding模型。在特定领域或任务中，Custom Embedding能够更准确地捕捉数据的内在规律和语义信息。通常需要使用深度学习模型，并在大规模标注数据集上进行训练。\n\n### （4）用户提问",
      "score": 0.06992833,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "title": "RAG-检索增强生成从入门到实战，看这一篇就够了 - 知乎",
      "url": "https://www.zhihu.com/tardis/bd/art/10769642350",
      "content": "5 赞同\n\n20 收藏\n\nRAG（检索增强生成）是一种结合了信息检索技术与语言生成模型的人工智能技术，旨在提升大型语言模型处理知识密集型任务的能力。以下是关于RAG的详细介绍：\n\nRAG技术简介\n\nRAG（Retrieval-Augmented Generation）技术通过从外部知识库中检索相关信息，并将其作为提示（Prompt）输入给大型语言模型（LLMs），以增强模型处理知识密集型任务的能力。这种方法特别适用于那些高度依赖专业知识的任务，能够显著提升回答的精确度。\n\nRAG的主要模块\n\n 版面分析：读取本地知识文件，进行知识文件复原。\n 知识库构建：包括知识文本分割、构建文档文本嵌入、构建索引。\n 大模型微调：对大模型进行微调，以适应特定的知识库。\n 基于RAG的知识问答：包括用户query嵌入、召回、排序、拼接文档、构建context、基于query和context构建prompt、将prompt喂给大模型生成答案。\n\nRAG的工作原理\n\nRAG的工作原理可以概括为以下几个步骤： [...] 由于新岗位的生产效率，要优于被取代岗位的生产效率，所以实际上整个社会的生产效率是提升的。\n\n但是具体到个人，只能说是：\n\n“最先掌握AI的人，将会比较晚掌握AI的人有竞争优势”。\n\n这句话，放在计算机、互联网、移动互联网的开局时期，都是一样的道理。\n\n我在一线互联网企业工作十余年里，指导过不少同行后辈。帮助很多人得到了学习和成长。\n\n我意识到有很多经验和知识值得分享给大家，也可以通过我们的能力和经验解答大家在人工智能学习中的很多困惑，所以在工作繁忙的情况下还是坚持各种整理和分享。但苦于知识传播途径有限，很多互联网行业朋友无法获得正确的资料得到学习提升，故此将并将重要的AI大模型资料包括AI大模型入门学习思维导图、精品AI大模型学习书籍手册、视频教程、实战学习等录播视频免费分享出来。\n\n这份完整版的大模型 AI 学习资料已经上传，朋友们如果需要可以点击 下方卡片 免费领取【`保证100%免费`】\n\n## 第一阶段（10天）：初阶应用 [...] 为什么要做 RAG\n 搭建一个简单的 ChatPDF\n 检索的基础概念\n 什么是向量表示（Embeddings）\n 向量数据库与向量检索\n 基于向量检索的 RAG\n 搭建 RAG 系统的扩展知识\n 混合检索与 RAG-Fusion 简介\n 向量模型本地部署\n ....\n\n## 第三阶段（30天）：模型训练\n\n恭喜你，如果学到这里，你基本可以找到一份大模型 AI相关的工作，自己也能训练 GPT 了！通过微调，训练自己的垂直大模型，能独立训练开源多模态大模型，掌握更多技术方案。\n\n到此为止，大概2个月的时间。你已经成为了一名“AI小子”。那么你还想往下探索吗？\n\n 为什么要做 RAG\n 什么是模型\n 什么是模型训练\n 求解器 & 损失函数简介\n 小实验2：手写一个简单的神经网络并训练它\n 什么是训练/预训练/微调/轻量化微调\n Transformer结构简介\n 轻量化微调\n 实验数据集的构建\n ....\n\n## 第四阶段（20天）：商业闭环",

      "title": "大模型时代，目前开源的RAG检索增强框架有哪些？ - 知乎",

    {
      "title": "GraphRAG：知识图谱+大模型",
      "url": "https://www.zhihu.com/tardis/zm/art/660722382",
      "content": "``` [...] ``` [...] RAG（Retrieval Argumented Generation）指的是通过 RAG 模型来对搜索结果进行增强的过程。具体来说，它是将检索技术和语言生成技术相结合来增强生成过程的一种技术，可以帮助传统搜索引擎生成更加准确、相关和多样化的信息来满足用户的需求。\n\nGraph RAG是一种基于知识图谱的检索增强技术，通过构建图模型的知识表达，将实体和关系之间的联系用图的形式进行展示，然后利用大语言模型 LLM进行检索增强。\n\nGraph RAG 将知识图谱等价于一个超大规模的词汇表，而实体和关系则对应于单词。通过这种方式，Graph RAG 在检索时能够将实体和关系作为单元进行联合建模。\n\n一个简单的 Graph RAG 思想在于，对用户输入的query提取实体，然后构造子图形成上下文，最后送入大模型完成生成。\n\n## 代码示例：",
      "score": 0.06151994,
      "raw_content": null
    },

From the apps Application menu, select Settings > Parsers.\n2. Click more\\_vertMenu for the required prebuilt parser.\n3. Click Turn on auto updates.\n\n### Update a parser version manually\n\nIf automatic updates are off, you can choose when to update a parser to a new version. This lets you review changes before applying them. [...] To switch back to the previous parser version, follow these steps:\n\n1. From the apps Application menu, select Settings > Parsers.\n2. Click more\\_vert Menu against the parser that you want to revert.\n3. Click View.\n\n   The View prebuilt parser page appears.\n4. Click Revert to previous version.       "content": "The release of Qwen-Image-2512 reinforces a broader shift: open-source AI is no longer content to trail proprietary systems by a generation. Instead, it is selectively matching the capabilities that matter most for enterprise deployment—text fidelity, layout control, and realism—while preserving the freedoms enterprises increasingly demand. [...] The API accepts text input and returns image output, with rate limits suitable for production workloads. Free quotas are limited, and usage transitions to paid billing once credits are exhausted.\n\nThis hybrid approach—open weights paired with a commercial API—mirrors how many enterprises deploy AI today: experimentation and customization in-house, with managed services layered on where operational simplicity matters.\n\n### Competitive, but philosophically different [...] All Posts\n\n# Open source Qwen-Image-2512 launches to compete with Google's Nano Banana Pro in high quality AI image generation\n\nCarl Franzen\n\nWhen Google released its newest AI image model Nano Banana Pro (aka Gemini 3 Pro Image) in November, it reset expectations for the entire field.\n\nFor the first time, uses of an image model could use natural language to generate dense, text-heavy infographics, slides, and other enterprise-grade visuals without spelling errors.",

      "content": "#### What is Workday Extend?\n\nWorkday Extend allows users to create custom applications that work alongside or in tandem with other Workday applications. Workday Extend is made up of various app components to create the custom process logic, pages and appearances of the applications. The three main app components are Presentation, Model and Orchestration. [...] This app is an employee experience app created for a commercial real estate client. Like the CEO Excellence Award App, this app gives employees the opportunity to nominate other employees who uphold the company’s mission and values. The app was created to improve employee morale and satisfaction. Workday Extend apps allowed the developer to create the application in Workday, giving it a similar look to their other applications, making using it easy to learn. [...] Below are examples of real-world uses of Workday Extend that Cognizant’s Workday practice built for our clients to help meet their specific needs. AI agents will introduce new frameworks for enterprise systems, workforce design, and decision-making models. The most important developments to watch include: [...] Rather than displace jobs, agentic AI changes the nature of work. Agents take on repeatable, decision-bound tasks that follow clear logic or structured workflows. In doing so, they free up people to focus on work centered on creativity, intuition, innovation, and the ability to adapt amidst change and uncertainty.\n\nThis shift raises new requirements for how organizations design work.     {
      "title": "\"workday\" or \"work day\" | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-or-work-day.2945218/",
      "content": "Workday (noun) = (i) days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Next Monday is a public holiday, but Tuesday will be a normal workday. (ii) days upon which specific people work, e.g. \"Saturday and Sunday are normal workdays for policemen.\"  \n (i) adjective relating to days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Today, she would not go anywhere special, so she put on her workday clothes.\"  \n   \n  more commonly \"working day\". [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# \"workday\" or \"work day\"\n\n Thread starter w3lifer\n Start date\n\n#### w3lifer\n\n##### New Member\n\nPlanet Earth\n\nRussian, Belorussian\n\n #1\n\nHello.  \n What is the difference between \"workday\" and \"work day\"?  \n Why do some people write \"workday\", others — \"work day\"?\n\n#### KHS\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA\n\nUSA - English L1\n\n #2 [...] In general, if it's an adjective, it will be written as one word but if it is being used with \"day\" as a noun, it will be written as two words. The same is true for \"every day\" and \"everyday\"  \n   \n The workday world can be difficult.  \n I missed three work days due to illness.  \n   \n The everyday habits of my friend are just like mine.  \n I have classes every day, Monday through Friday.  \n   \n That's just a general pattern, and I can't guarantee that it will always be followed.\n\n#### PaulQ",
      "score": 0.05886858,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "title": "workday, working day - WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-working-day.1502173/",
      "content": "A workday or work day is a day on which you work: Monday to Friday, normally. A working day could be the same as that, but is perhaps more often used for the hours of the day you're at work. If something happens during the working day, it happens between 9 and 5.30 or whenever. My working day was busy yesterday.\n\nS\n\n#### sasmith\n\n##### Member\n\nBritish English\n\n #5 [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# workday, working day\n\n Thread starter belissimo\n Start date\n\n#### belissimo\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nRussia, Moscow\n\nRussian\n\n #1\n\nHello,  \n If these words are synonyms,  \n which of them is the most used:workday or working day?  \n Thanks\n\nM\n\n#### mgcrules\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - Australia\n\n #2\n\nwork day is more common for me.\n\n#### belissimo [...] So, you might say 'As Wednesday was a work day, I couldn't stay up late on Tuesday'; or 'I always spend the working day dreaming of holidays'.",
      "score": 0.057139874,
      "raw_content": null

      "title": "Difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/difference-between-working-days-and-weekdays.2566775/",
      "content": "aren't counted in 'working days'. [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# Difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"\n\n Thread starter annjuks\n Start date\n\nA\n\n#### annjuks\n\n##### Member\n\nLatvia\n\nLatvian\n\n #1\n\nHello,  \n What's the difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"? Is the second one used more frequently than the first? (In the examples like \"the centre is open on working days/ weekdays\")\n\nLast edited: [...] Yes, weekdays are the days from Monday to Friday, as opposed to the weekend. This is the usual expression if you mean those five days. We'd talk about working days only if there was a possibility of them being different - so 'working days' excludes public holidays. A bank might guarantee to clear a cheque (put the money in your account) within three working days. So if you put it in on the Thursday the day before Easter, you might not get the money for almost a week, because the Easter holidays",
      "score": 0.04574752,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "weekday / holiday | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/weekday-holiday.3689011/",
      "content": "And 'workday' is meaningless when one is retired and on vacation and thus more likely to visit a museum on a Thursday morning, when all working folk are at work. [...] \"Workday\" and \"working day\" are theoretically possible. But in reality a museum wouldn't use those words in the listing of the hours when it's open. Visitors who are not native speakers would be much more likely to be confused by the word 'workday' (which is probably not easily found in the average English phrase book) than by 'Monday', which is more easily found. [...] Several words/phrases are quite frequently used: workday, work day, weekday, business day\n\n#### kentix\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - U.S.\n\n #16\n\nI would just ask them, \"What time do you get up on days you have to work?\"  \n   \n That covers all possibilities, including if they work Saturday or Sunday.\n\n#### kentix\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - U.S.\n\n #17",

[...] _Next week Saturday is a working day (_ or _workday) for me, so I can't play golf then._ Si j'ai bien compris l'exemple donné par staarkali, ça pourrait être l'équivalent de _jour ouvré._\n\n Similarly, we would say a _school day_ when school is scheduled, and a _school night_ to describe the night before you have school, when you would tell a child to go to bed early.\n\n Monday-Friday is the _workweek_ --_la semaine ouvrable_?       "title": "I will shut up now vs I'll be shutting up now - WordReference...",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/i-will-shut-up-now-vs-ill-be-shutting-up-now.4008014/",
      "content": "> Roxxxannne said:\n>\n> I will/I'll [verb] and I'll be [verb]-ing are both American, but I will/I'll [verb] is more common. I think the use of I'll be [verb]-ing depends on the verb. For instance, I'll be leaving now is used fairly often compared to I'll leave now.  \n>    \n>  I've never heard anyone say I'll be shutting up now to refer to not talking. I can imagine a manager of a store saying it at the end of the workday, though.\n>\n> Click to expand... [...] > Hiden said:\n>\n> (1) I will shut up now.​\n>\n> (2) I'll be shutting up now.​\n>\n> Click to expand... [...] > Click to expand...",

It contains all data items that have been added for the organization. Assigning the All data profile to a role attribute for a user grants the user access to all data items.\n\nCustom, or user defined, data profiles are data profiles to which you can assign specific data items.       "content": "You are here:\n\n# About Setting Up Roles and Users\n\nDayforce Identity Access Management (IAM) controls access to partner applications, other pages of theIdentity Access Management, and data through roles and users.\n\n## Contents\n\nRoles [Top](#)\n\nIdentity Access Management automatically adds the IAM Customer User role and IAM Customer Admin role as standard roles for every organization. [...] IAM Customer User - Most commonly-assigned role used by all users of an organization to access partner applications, and manage self-service functions such as changing your password and secret questions. All users are added to the IAM Customer User role during automatic provisioning.\n IAM Customer Admin - An organization administrative role used to manage user attributes, data profiles, and PSIDs, and set up the organization's security policy. [...] Add users using the File Import feature described in Managing File Imports.\n Provision users using a web service that extracts user information and loads it into Identity Access Management. At this time we offer web services only for PowerPay and Solution Centre users.\n Add users manually in the Identity Access Management\n\n## Related resources\n\n Users",

    {
      "title": "How we really judge AI - MIT News",
      "url": "https://news.mit.edu/2025/how-we-really-judge-ai-0610",
      "content": "“The meta-analysis supported our theoretical framework,” Lu says. “Both dimensions are important:Individuals evaluate whether or not AI is more capable than people at a given task, and whether the task calls for personalization. People will prefer AI only if they think the AI is more capable than humans and the task is nonpersonal.”\n\nHe adds: “The key idea here is that high perceived capability alone does not guarantee AI appreciation. Personalization matters too.” [...] For example, people tend to favor AI when it comes to detecting fraud or sorting large datasets — areas where AI’s abilities exceed those of humans in speed and scale, and personalization is not required. But they are more resistant to AI in contexts like therapy, job interviews, or medical diagnoses, where they feel a human is better able to recognize their unique circumstances. [...] A new study finds that people are neither entirely enthusiastic nor totally averse to AI. Rather than falling into camps of techno-optimists and Luddites, people are discerning about the practical upshot of using AI, case by case. \n\nCredits:\n\n Credit: Christine Daniloff, MIT; iStock \n\nPrevious image Next image",

      "content": "Because the diffusion model de-noises all pixels in an image at each step, and there may be 30 or more steps, the process is slow and computationally expensive. But because the model has multiple chances to correct details it got wrong, the images are high-quality. [...] “We can achieve a huge boost in terms of reconstruction quality. Our residual tokens learn high-frequency details, like edges of an object, or a person’s hair, eyes, or mouth. These are places where discrete tokens can make mistakes,” says Tang. Anonymized data is no longer considered to be personal data.\n\nanti-pattern\n:   A frequently used solution for a recurring issue where the solution is counter-productive, ineffective, or less effective than an alternative.       "content": "“Bias in employment arising from the use of algorithms and AI falls squarely within the Commission’s priority to address systemic discrimination,” Burrows said. “While the technology may be evolving, anti-discrimination laws still apply. The EEOC will address workplace bias that violates federal civil rights laws regardless of the form it takes, and the agency is committed to helping employers understand how to benefit from these new technologies while also complying with employment laws.” [...] Establish an internal working group to coordinate the agency’s work on the initiative;\n   Launch a series of listening sessions with key stakeholders about algorithmic tools and their employment ramifications;\n   Gather information about the adoption, design, and impact of hiring and other employment-related technologies;\n   Identify promising practices; and\n   Issue technical assistance to provide guidance on algorithmic fairness and the use of AI in employment decisions.       "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/roadmap-nist-artificial-intelligence-risk-management-framework-ai",
      "content": "6. Development of case studies about how the AI RMF has been used by a single organization or sector, context, or AI actor. Use cases may be similar to AI RMF profiles but can more directly describe organizational experiences and challenges using the AI RMF – and how they were addressed – along with information about resources, timeframes, and AI RMF effectiveness. [...] The Framework is intended to be voluntary, rights-preserving, non-sector specific, and use-case agnostic, providing flexibility to organizations of all sizes and in all sectors and throughout society to implement the approaches in the Framework. The AI RMF is designed to equip organizations and individuals – AI actors – with approaches that increase the trustworthiness of AI systems. [...] 3. AI RMF 1.0 Profiles. Profiles are a primary method for organizations to share real-life examples of how they put the AI RMF into practice. These profiles can be for a given industry sector (such as hiring, criminal justice, lending), cross-sectoral (such as large language models, cloud-based services or acquisition), temporal (such as current vs desired state), or other topics. Organizations and individuals are encouraged to jointly or independently produce AI RMF profiles.",

      "title": "AI Risk Management Framework | NIST",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework",
      "content": "In collaboration with the private and public sectors, NIST has developed a framework to better manage risks to individuals, organizations, and society associated with artificial intelligence (AI). The NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is intended for voluntary use and to improve the ability to incorporate trustworthiness considerations into the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI products, services, and systems. [...] A companion NIST AI RMF Playbook also has been published by NIST along with an AI RMF Roadmap \"), AI RMF Crosswalk \"), and various Perspectives.\n\nOn March 30, 2023, NIST launched the Trustworthy and Responsible AI Resource Center, which will facilitate implementation of, and international alignment with, the AI RMF. Examples of how other organizations are building on and using the AI RMF can be found via the AIRC’s Use Case page. [...] On July 26, 2024, NIST released NIST-AI-600-1, Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework: Generative Artificial Intelligence Profile. The profile  can help organizations identify unique risks posed by generative AI and proposes actions for generative AI risk management that best aligns with their goals and priorities.\n\nTo view public comments received on the previous drafts of the AI RMF and Requests for Information, see the AI RMF Development page.\n\n## Translations",

      "title": "AI RMF Development | NIST",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/ai-rmf-development",
      "content": "In collaboration with the private and public sectors, NIST has developed a framework to better manage risks to individuals, organizations, and society associated with artificial intelligence (AI). The NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is intended for voluntary use and to improve the ability to incorporate trustworthiness considerations into the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI products, services, and systems. [...] Released on January 26, 2023, the Framework was developed through a consensus-driven, open, transparent, and collaborative process that included a Request for Information, several draft versions for public comments, multiple workshops, and other opportunities to provide input. It is intended to build on, align with, and support AI risk management efforts by others.\n\nA companion NIST AI RMF Playbookalso has been published by NIST. [...] NIST released the first complete version of the NIST AI RMF Playbook on March 30, 2023\n\nNIST released the AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) 1.0. along with a companion NIST AI RMF Playbook, NIST AI RMF Video Explainer, an AI RMF Roadmap \"), AI RMF Crosswalks \"), and various Perspectives on January 26, 2023.\n\nNIST issued a second draft of the AI RMF for written comments and at the October 18-19, 2022, workshop.",
      "score": 0.7325349,

      "title": "AI RMF Resources - AIRC",
      "url": "https://airc.nist.gov/airmf-resources/",
      "content": "The\nAI RMF Core\nprovides outcomes and actions that enable dialogue, understanding, and activities to manage AI risks and\nresponsibility develop trustworthy AI systems. This is operationalized through four functions: Govern,\nMap, Measure, and Manage.\n\n## AI RMF Profiles\n\nThe use-case\nProfiles are\nimplementations of the AI RMF functions, categories, and subcategories for a specific setting or\napplication based on the requirements, risk tolerance, and resources of the Framework user. [...] National Institute of Standards and Technology logo\nClose\nSearch\n\n# AI Risk Management Framework\n\nThe AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is intended for voluntary use and to improve the ability to incorporate\ntrustworthiness considerations into the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI products, services, and\nsystems. [...] As a consensus resource, the AI RMF was developed in an open, transparent, multidisciplinary, and multistakeholder\nmanner over an 18-month time period and in collaboration with more than 240 contributing organizations from private\nindustry, academia, civil society, and government. Feedback received during the development of the AI RMF is\npublicly available on the NIST website.\n\nDownload the framework\n\n## Framing risk\n\n## Audience",

      "title": "Crosswalks to the NIST Artificial Intelligence Risk ...",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/crosswalks-nist-artificial-intelligence-risk-management-framework",
      "content": "The Framework is intended to be voluntary, rights-preserving, non-sector specific, and use-case agnostic, providing flexibility to organizations of all sizes and in all sectors and throughout society to implement the approaches in the Framework. The AI RMF is designed to equip organizations and individuals – AI actors – with approaches that increase the trustworthiness of AI systems . [...] NIST has preparedseveral crosswalksto the Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1.0). As directed by the National Artificial Intelligence Initiative Act of 2020 (P.L. 116-283), the goal of the AI RMF is to offer a voluntary resource to the organizations designing, developing, deploying, or using AI systems to help manage the many risks of AI and promote trustworthy and responsible development and use of AI systems. [...] The Framework is intended for use with, and to encourage the development of other AI resources, including guidance and standards. The NIST Roadmap for the AI RMF cites alignment with international standards as a top priority for the agency and the AI community.\n\nComments on these crosswalks and suggestions for additional crosswalks are welcomed by NIST at any time and should be addressed to AIframework [at] nist.gov (AIframework[at]nist[dot]gov).",
      "score": 0.7077487,
      "raw_content": null

      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework/nist-ai-rmf-playbook",
      "content": "In collaboration with the private and public sectors, NIST has created a companion AI RMF playbookfor voluntary use – which suggests ways to navigate and use the AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) to incorporate trustworthiness considerations in the design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems. [...] The AI RMF and the Playbook are intended for voluntary use. Organizations may utilize this information by borrowing as many – or as few – suggestions as apply to their industry use case or interests.\n\nPlaybook content will evolve to enable community review and feedback about its informativeness, accuracy and specificity. The first complete version announced on March 30, 2023, includes options for filtering or tailoring information to user preferences and requirements. [...] The Playbook is based on AI RMF 1.0 (released on January 26, 2023). It includes suggested actions, references, and related guidance to achieve the outcomes for the four functions in the AI RMF: Govern, Map, Measure, and Manage. Playbook suggestions are developed based on best practices and research insights.",

      "content": "Nested Learning pushes the same theme from another angle. It treats a model as a set of nested optimization problems, each with its own internal workflow, and uses that framing to address catastrophic forgetting. [...] Continual learning shifts rigor toward memory provenance and retention. World models shift it toward robust simulation and prediction of real-world events. Orchestration shifts it toward better use of resources. Refinement shifts it toward smart reflection and correction of answers.\n\nThe winners will not only pick strong models, they will build the control plane that keeps those models correct, current, and cost-efficient.\n\n## More [...] Refinement techniques turn “one answer” into a controlled process: propose, critique, revise, and verify.       "content": "In looking at the company’s longer-term digital evolution, company leaders recognized that their traditional business was becoming more complex. [...] segmentation across its environment, it was also critical for the company to train both IT staff and internal end users. The manufacturer decided to implement the solutions and configurations recommended by Deloitte.       "url": "https://partners.wsj.com/mckinsey/leading-change/human-skills-will-matter-more-than-ever-in-the-age-of-ai/",
      "title": "Human Skills Will Matter More Than Ever in the Age of AI",
      "content": "The rise of AI is understandably unsettling for workers. But new research from the McKinsey Global Institute shows its impact is far more complicated—and far less alarming—than the headlines imply. According to the study, existing technologies could automate tasks that make up more than half of U.S. work hours today. It’s a big number, but it does not translate into a wholesale disappearance of jobs. Instead, most of the change will come from people doing different things in their workday. The [...] There’s no doubt that some jobs will shrink in the AI age. Others will expand or change, and new ones will emerge. The transition will be challenging for workers and businesses. But organizations that help people build the skills needed to work with AI will capture far more value than those that simply deploy new tools.\n\nAI will transform tasks. But human work will endure. The companies that succeed will invest in their people as a core asset, not just in technology. [...] AI absorbs more chores like sifting information, organizing data and drafting basic content, workers will have to lean more heavily on the capabilities machines do not yet offer: judgment, relationship-building, critical thinking and empathy.",

      "title": "Four AI research trends enterprise teams should watch in ...",
      "content": "Continual learning shifts rigor toward memory provenance and retention. World models shift it toward robust simulation and prediction of real-world events. Orchestration shifts it toward better use of resources. Refinement shifts it toward smart reflection and correction of answers.\n\nThe winners will not only pick strong models, they will build the control plane that keeps those models correct, current, and cost-efficient.\n\n## More [...] logs. [...] Standard transformer-based language models have dense layers that store the long-term memory obtained during pretraining and attention layers that hold the immediate context. Nested Learning introduces a “continuum memory system,” where memory is seen as a spectrum of modules that update at different frequencies. This creates a memory system that is more attuned to continual learning.",

      "url": "https://venturebeat.com/technology/four-ai-research-trends-enterprise-teams-should-watch-in-2026",
      "title": "Four AI research trends enterprise teams should watch in ...",
      "content": "World Labs, a new startup founded by AI pioneer Fei-Fei Li, takes a slightly different approach. Marble, World Labs’ first AI system, uses generative AI to create a 3D model from an image or a prompt, which can then be used by a physics and 3D engine to render and simulate the interactive environment used to train robots. [...] There are different approaches for creating world models. DeepMind is building Genie, a family of generative end-to-end models that simulate an environment so an agent can predict how the environment will evolve and how actions will change it. It takes in an image or prompt along with user actions and generates the sequence of video frames that reflect how the world changes. Genie can create interactive environments that can be used for different purposes, including training robots and [...] JEPA models are much more efficient than generative models, which makes them suitable for fast-paced real-time AI applications that need to run on resource constrained devices. V-JEPA, the video version of the architecture, is pre-trained on unlabeled internet-scale video to learn world models through observation. It then adds a small amount of interaction data from robot trajectories to support planning. That combination hints at a path where enterprises leverage abundant passive video",

If you haven't exceeded your API limit, try re-running the connector.       "content": "Oz Wiki\nOz Wiki\n\n# Gugu and the Kalidahs\n\n\"Gugu and the Kalidahs\" is a non-canonical Oz story written by Eric Shanower, published in Oz-story Magazine No. 1 in 1995. It was reprinted in The Salt Sorcerer of Oz and Other Stories. The story is in the genre of animal fable that was a favorite of L. Frank Baum and often employed by him. [...] Gugu, the ruler of his forest, learns that renegade kalidahs from the east have penetrated his territory. The kalidahs' lands are adjacent to his own, but jungle law forbids trespassing in either direction. At great risk to himself, Gugu consults with the kalidah king, who is unwilling to interfere; whether Gugu defeats the renegades or vice versa, the king's ends are served. Gugu and his subjects, both the stronger (elephants) and the humbler (gophers), must co-operate to survive and triumph; [...] Shanower draws upon Baum's The Magic of Oz (1919) for his inspiration. Baum introduced the Forest of Gugu and its eponymous ruler in that book. Baum had created kalidahs, fierce creatures with the bodies of bears and the heads of tigers, in his inaugural Oz book \"The Wonderful Wizard of Oz (book)\"), but he returned them to action in The Magic of Oz. In bringing the two elements together, Shanower crafts a might-versus-right tale with undertones of cynical realpolitik.",
      "score": 0.016179273,
      "raw_content": null

      "url": "https://partners.wsj.com/mckinsey/leading-change/human-skills-will-matter-more-than-ever-in-the-age-of-ai/",
      "title": "Human Skills Will Matter More Than Ever in the Age of AI",
      "content": "The rise of AI is understandably unsettling for workers. But new research from the McKinsey Global Institute shows its impact is far more complicated—and far less alarming—than the headlines imply. According to the study, existing technologies could automate tasks that make up more than half of U.S. work hours today. It’s a big number, but it does not translate into a wholesale disappearance of jobs. Instead, most of the change will come from people doing different things in their workday. The [...] AI absorbs more chores like sifting information, organizing data and drafting basic content, workers will have to lean more heavily on the capabilities machines do not yet offer: judgment, relationship-building, critical thinking and empathy. [...] Second, pinpoint the skills that workers, and managers in particular, will need to collaborate effectively with AI. These include technical fluency as well as capabilities specific to human-AI interaction: framing problems, overseeing AI outputs, interpreting results, managing exceptions and knowing when to escalate decisions. Success should be measured by how well people and AI create value together, not by the volume of tools deployed.",

According to the study, existing technologies could automate tasks that make up more than half of U.S. work hours today. It’s a big number, but it does not translate into a wholesale disappearance of jobs. Instead, most of the change will come from people doing different things in their workday. [...] Second, pinpoint the skills that workers, and managers in particular, will need to collaborate effectively with AI. These include technical fluency as well as capabilities specific to human-AI interaction: framing problems, overseeing AI outputs, interpreting results, managing exceptions and knowing when to escalate decisions.     {
      "url": "https://partners.wsj.com/mckinsey/leading-change/human-skills-will-matter-more-than-ever-in-the-age-of-ai/",
      "title": "Human Skills Will Matter More Than Ever in the Age of AI",
      "content": "The rise of AI is understandably unsettling for workers. But new research from the McKinsey Global Institute shows its impact is far more complicated—and far less alarming—than the headlines imply. According to the study, existing technologies could automate tasks that make up more than half of U.S. work hours today. It’s a big number, but it does not translate into a wholesale disappearance of jobs. Instead, most of the change will come from people doing different things in their workday. The [...] AI absorbs more chores like sifting information, organizing data and drafting basic content, workers will have to lean more heavily on the capabilities machines do not yet offer: judgment, relationship-building, critical thinking and empathy. [...] Second, pinpoint the skills that workers, and managers in particular, will need to collaborate effectively with AI. These include technical fluency as well as capabilities specific to human-AI interaction: framing problems, overseeing AI outputs, interpreting results, managing exceptions and knowing when to escalate decisions. Success should be measured by how well people and AI create value together, not by the volume of tools deployed.",
      "score": 0.44941738,

      "url": "https://partners.wsj.com/mckinsey/leading-change/human-skills-will-matter-more-than-ever-in-the-age-of-ai/",
      "title": "Human Skills Will Matter More Than Ever in the Age of AI",
      "content": "The rise of AI is understandably unsettling for workers. But new research from the McKinsey Global Institute shows its impact is far more complicated—and far less alarming—than the headlines imply. According to the study, existing technologies could automate tasks that make up more than half of U.S. work hours today. It’s a big number, but it does not translate into a wholesale disappearance of jobs. Instead, most of the change will come from people doing different things in their workday. The [...] AI absorbs more chores like sifting information, organizing data and drafting basic content, workers will have to lean more heavily on the capabilities machines do not yet offer: judgment, relationship-building, critical thinking and empathy. [...] Second, pinpoint the skills that workers, and managers in particular, will need to collaborate effectively with AI. These include technical fluency as well as capabilities specific to human-AI interaction: framing problems, overseeing AI outputs, interpreting results, managing exceptions and knowing when to escalate decisions. Success should be measured by how well people and AI create value together, not by the volume of tools deployed.",

      "content": "The API accepts text input and returns image output, with rate limits suitable for production workloads. Free quotas are limited, and usage transitions to paid billing once credits are exhausted.\n\nThis hybrid approach—open weights paired with a commercial API—mirrors how many enterprises deploy AI today: experimentation and customization in-house, with managed services layered on where operational simplicity matters.\n\n### Competitive, but philosophically different [...] The release of Qwen-Image-2512 reinforces a broader shift: open-source AI is no longer content to trail proprietary systems by a generation. Instead, it is selectively matching the capabilities that matter most for enterprise deployment—text fidelity, layout control, and realism—while preserving the freedoms enterprises increasingly demand.",

More importantly, world models open the way for AI systems that can move beyond text and solve tasks that involve physical environments. Marble, World Labs’ first AI system, uses generative AI to create a 3D model from an image or a prompt, which can then be used by a physics and 3D engine to render and simulate the interactive environment used to train robots.     },
    {
      "title": "\"workday\" or \"work day\" | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-or-work-day.2945218/",
      "content": "Workday (noun) = (i) days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Next Monday is a public holiday, but Tuesday will be a normal workday. (ii) days upon which specific people work, e.g. \"Saturday and Sunday are normal workdays for policemen.\"  \n (i) adjective relating to days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Today, she would not go anywhere special, so she put on her workday clothes.\"  \n   \n  more commonly \"working day\". [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# \"workday\" or \"work day\"\n\n Thread starter w3lifer\n Start date\n\n#### w3lifer\n\n##### New Member\n\nPlanet Earth\n\nRussian, Belorussian\n\n #1\n\nHello.  \n What is the difference between \"workday\" and \"work day\"?  \n Why do some people write \"workday\", others — \"work day\"?\n\n#### KHS\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA\n\nUSA - English L1\n\n #2 [...] WordReference.com Language Forums\n\n Rules/Help/FAQ \n\n  Help/FAQ\n Members \n\n  Current visitors\n Interface Language\n\nMenu\n\nLog in\n\nRegister\n\nInstall the app\n\nHow to install the app on iOS\n\nFollow along with the video below to see how to install our site as a web app on your home screen.\n\nNote: This feature may not be available in some browsers.\n\n English Only\n English Only",

    {
      "title": "workday, working day - WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-working-day.1502173/",
      "content": "A workday or work day is a day on which you work: Monday to Friday, normally. A working day could be the same as that, but is perhaps more often used for the hours of the day you're at work. If something happens during the working day, it happens between 9 and 5.30 or whenever. My working day was busy yesterday.\n\nS\n\n#### sasmith\n\n##### Member\n\nBritish English\n\n #5 [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# workday, working day\n\n Thread starter belissimo\n Start date\n\n#### belissimo\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nRussia, Moscow\n\nRussian\n\n #1\n\nHello,  \n If these words are synonyms,  \n which of them is the most used:workday or working day?  \n Thanks\n\nM\n\n#### mgcrules\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - Australia\n\n #2\n\nwork day is more common for me.\n\n#### belissimo [...] WordReference.com Language Forums\n\n Rules/Help/FAQ\n Members \n\n  Current visitors\n Interface Language\n\nMenu\n\nLog in\n\nRegister\n\nInstall the app\n\nHow to install the app on iOS\n\nFollow along with the video below to see how to install our site as a web app on your home screen.\n\nNote: This feature may not be available in some browsers.\n\n English Only\n English Only",

    {
      "title": "\"workday\" or \"work day\" | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-or-work-day.2945218/",
      "content": "Workday (noun) = (i) days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Next Monday is a public holiday, but Tuesday will be a normal workday. (ii) days upon which specific people work, e.g. \"Saturday and Sunday are normal workdays for policemen.\"  \n (i) adjective relating to days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Today, she would not go anywhere special, so she put on her workday clothes.\"  \n   \n  more commonly \"working day\". [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# \"workday\" or \"work day\"\n\n Thread starter w3lifer\n Start date\n\n#### w3lifer\n\n##### New Member\n\nPlanet Earth\n\nRussian, Belorussian\n\n #1\n\nHello.  \n What is the difference between \"workday\" and \"work day\"?  \n Why do some people write \"workday\", others — \"work day\"?\n\n#### KHS\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA\n\nUSA - English L1\n\n #2 [...] In general, if it's an adjective, it will be written as one word but if it is being used with \"day\" as a noun, it will be written as two words. The same is true for \"every day\" and \"everyday\"  \n   \n The workday world can be difficult.  \n I missed three work days due to illness.  \n   \n The everyday habits of my friend are just like mine.  \n I have classes every day, Monday through Friday.  \n   \n That's just a general pattern, and I can't guarantee that it will always be followed.\n\n#### PaulQ",
      "score": 0.038138922,
      "raw_content": null

      "content": "And 'workday' is meaningless when one is retired and on vacation and thus more likely to visit a museum on a Thursday morning, when all working folk are at work. [...] WordReference.com Language Forums\n\n Rules/Help/FAQ\n Members \n\n  Current visitors\n Interface Language\n\nLog in\n\n---\n\nInstall the app\n\nHow to install the app on iOS\n\nFollow along with the video below to see how to install our site as a web app on your home screen.\n\nNote: This feature may not be available in some browsers.\n\n English Only\n English Only\n\nYou are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser. [...] \"Workday\" and \"working day\" are theoretically possible. But in reality a museum wouldn't use those words in the listing of the hours when it's open. Visitors who are not native speakers would be much more likely to be confused by the word 'workday' (which is probably not easily found in the average English phrase book) than by 'Monday', which is more easily found.",

      "url": "https://venturebeat.com/technology/four-ai-research-trends-enterprise-teams-should-watch-in-2026",
      "title": "Four AI research trends enterprise teams should watch in ...",
      "content": "At VentureBeat, we are tracking AI research that can help understand where the practical implementation of technology is heading. We are looking forward to breakthroughs that are not just about the raw intelligence of a single model, but about how we engineer the systems around them. As we approach 2026, here are four trends that can represent the blueprint for the next generation of robust, scalable enterprise applications.\n\n## Continual learning [...] There are now multiple frameworks that create orchestration layers to improve efficiency and accuracy of AI agents, especially when using external tools. Stanford's OctoTools is an open-source framework that can orchestrate multiple tools without the need to fine-tune or adjust the models. OctoTools uses a modular approach that plans a solution, selects tools, and passes subtasks to different agents. OctoTools can use any general-purpose LLM as its backbone. [...] There are different approaches for creating world models. DeepMind is building Genie, a family of generative end-to-end models that simulate an environment so an agent can predict how the environment will evolve and how actions will change it. It takes in an image or prompt along with user actions and generates the sequence of video frames that reflect how the world changes. Genie can create interactive environments that can be used for different purposes, including training robots and",

    {
      "title": "\"workday\" or \"work day\" | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-or-work-day.2945218/",
      "content": "Workday (noun) = (i) days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Next Monday is a public holiday, but Tuesday will be a normal workday. (ii) days upon which specific people work, e.g. \"Saturday and Sunday are normal workdays for policemen.\"  \n (i) adjective relating to days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Today, she would not go anywhere special, so she put on her workday clothes.\"  \n   \n  more commonly \"working day\". [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# \"workday\" or \"work day\"\n\n Thread starter w3lifer\n Start date\n\n#### w3lifer\n\n##### New Member\n\nPlanet Earth\n\nRussian, Belorussian\n\n #1\n\nHello.  \n What is the difference between \"workday\" and \"work day\"?  \n Why do some people write \"workday\", others — \"work day\"?\n\n#### KHS\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA\n\nUSA - English L1\n\n #2 [...] To me (BE) there are 3 words:  \n   \n \"Workaday\" (adjective) = mundane; common; usual; standard (of quality); \"The new cell phone is not remarkable at all, it has a workaday processor and last year's screen.\" (Often used in the phrase \"[in the] workaday world of high finance/professional football/aviation/teaching, etc, etc.\" meaning 'normal and not exciting area of activity')",
      "score": 0.08568649,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "workday, working day - WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-working-day.1502173/",
      "content": "A workday or work day is a day on which you work: Monday to Friday, normally. A working day could be the same as that, but is perhaps more often used for the hours of the day you're at work. If something happens during the working day, it happens between 9 and 5.30 or whenever. My working day was busy yesterday.\n\nS\n\n#### sasmith\n\n##### Member\n\nBritish English\n\n #5 [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# workday, working day\n\n Thread starter belissimo\n Start date\n\n#### belissimo\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nRussia, Moscow\n\nRussian\n\n #1\n\nHello,  \n If these words are synonyms,  \n which of them is the most used:workday or working day?  \n Thanks\n\nM\n\n#### mgcrules\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - Australia\n\n #2\n\nwork day is more common for me.\n\n#### belissimo [...] So, you might say 'As Wednesday was a work day, I couldn't stay up late on Tuesday'; or 'I always spend the working day dreaming of holidays'.",

      "title": "Difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/difference-between-working-days-and-weekdays.2566775/",
      "content": "aren't counted in 'working days'. [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# Difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"\n\n Thread starter annjuks\n Start date\n\nA\n\n#### annjuks\n\n##### Member\n\nLatvia\n\nLatvian\n\n #1\n\nHello,  \n What's the difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"? Is the second one used more frequently than the first? (In the examples like \"the centre is open on working days/ weekdays\")\n\nLast edited: [...] Yes, weekdays are the days from Monday to Friday, as opposed to the weekend. This is the usual expression if you mean those five days. We'd talk about working days only if there was a possibility of them being different - so 'working days' excludes public holidays. A bank might guarantee to clear a cheque (put the money in your account) within three working days. So if you put it in on the Thursday the day before Easter, you might not get the money for almost a week, because the Easter holidays",
      "score": 0.066721186,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "weekday / holiday | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/weekday-holiday.3689011/",
      "content": "And 'workday' is meaningless when one is retired and on vacation and thus more likely to visit a museum on a Thursday morning, when all working folk are at work. [...] \"Workday\" and \"working day\" are theoretically possible. But in reality a museum wouldn't use those words in the listing of the hours when it's open. Visitors who are not native speakers would be much more likely to be confused by the word 'workday' (which is probably not easily found in the average English phrase book) than by 'Monday', which is more easily found. [...] This system is also used to determine bus schedules and, in big cities, when you have to move your car to the other side of the road for the street sweepers.",

Instead, it’s enhancing their capabilities and acting as a strategic partner in accomplishing HR goals.\n\nThe latest Workday AI Indicator Report found that 40% of HR leaders say AI is helping their teams deliver more strategic value—and that number jumps to 54% among organizations that consider themselves AI pioneers.       "title": "Talent Sourcing Done Right in the Age of AI | Workday US",
      "url": "https://blog.workday.com/en-us/talent-sourcing-done-right-age-ai.html",
      "content": "Agentic AI represents the next wave of intelligent systems—tools that not only analyze and generate insights, but also take proactive action based on context and goals. These AI agents act more like a digital assistant that works alongside the recruiter.\n\nIn practice, agentic AI can: [...] Adoption of AI in HR is steadily on the rise, and 2024 was a big year for it. Korn Ferry reports that 67% of HR leaders see increased AI usage as a top talent acquisition trend for 2025. [...] Example: An agentic AI tool might notice that a particular role hasn’t attracted qualified applicants. It can prompt the recruiter to revisit the job description, and suggest changes based on market data—all without being asked.\n\n> Recruitment is ranked in the top three areas where HR leaders envision AI delivering immediate value.\n\n## The Benefits of AI Talent Sourcing Tools",

    {
      "title": "\"workday\" or \"work day\" | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-or-work-day.2945218/",
      "content": "Workday (noun) = (i) days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Next Monday is a public holiday, but Tuesday will be a normal workday. (ii) days upon which specific people work, e.g. \"Saturday and Sunday are normal workdays for policemen.\"  \n (i) adjective relating to days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Today, she would not go anywhere special, so she put on her workday clothes.\"  \n   \n  more commonly \"working day\". [...] In general, if it's an adjective, it will be written as one word but if it is being used with \"day\" as a noun, it will be written as two words. The same is true for \"every day\" and \"everyday\"  \n   \n The workday world can be difficult.  \n I missed three work days due to illness.  \n   \n The everyday habits of my friend are just like mine.  \n I have classes every day, Monday through Friday.  \n   \n That's just a general pattern, and I can't guarantee that it will always be followed.\n\n#### PaulQ [...] #### KHS\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA\n\nUSA - English L1\n\n #6\n\nw3lifer - PaulQ is right, and I am wrong. I assumed \"workday/work day\" followed the usual pattern, but it doesn't.\n\nYou must log in or register to reply here.\n\nShare:\n\nBluesky   LinkedIn   WhatsApp   Email   Share   Link\n\n English Only\n English Only\n\nTop Bottom",
      "score": 0.06124987,
      "raw_content": null
    },

    {
      "title": "workday, working day - WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-working-day.1502173/",
      "content": "A workday or work day is a day on which you work: Monday to Friday, normally. A working day could be the same as that, but is perhaps more often used for the hours of the day you're at work. If something happens during the working day, it happens between 9 and 5.30 or whenever. My working day was busy yesterday.\n\nS\n\n#### sasmith\n\n##### Member\n\nBritish English\n\n #5 [...] In AmE, @velisarius' sentence would usually be 'must be paid within 10 business days.' But I agree with the dictionaries that say 'workday' is AmE: I have an eight-hour workday, there are only four workdays this week, etc.\n\nYou must log in or register to reply here.\n\nShare:\n\nBluesky   LinkedIn   WhatsApp   Email   Share   Link\n\n English Only\n English Only\n\nTop Bottom [...] I think work day is more common than workday.  \n   \n Strangely, in my organisation (wider ?) Monday for me (I only work four days a week) is classed as my 'non-working day' rather than non-work day/workday.\n\n#### belissimo\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nRussia, Moscow\n\nRussian\n\n #6\n\nSo working day is similar to working hours?\n\nS\n\n#### sasmith\n\n##### Member\n\nBritish English\n\n #7\n\n> belissimo said:\n>\n> So working day is similar to working hours?\n>\n> Click to expand...",
      "score": 0.051429514,
      "raw_content": null

    {
      "title": "seeking vs. to seek - WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/seeking-vs-to-seek.4076594/",
      "content": "Either way, adjective clause or adverbial clause, the reduced non-finite/participial clause \"seeking an eight hour workday\" is a modifier; that's its grammatical function in the sentence. It's just that we can' tell if its an adjectival modifier or an adverbial modifier. Not that it matters. The overall message is the same, one way or the other. [...] >  Either way, adjective clause or adverbial clause, the reduced non-finite/participial clause \"seeking an eight hour workday\" is a modifier; that's its grammatical function in the sentence. It's just that we can' tell if its an adjectival modifier or an adverbial modifier. Not that it matters. The overall message is the same, one way or the other.\n> \n> \n> \n>  Yes, you can, but you still have the same issue: an incomplete non-finite clause, with an infinitive rather than a participle:\n> \n> \n> [...] :\n> \n> \n> \n> [_US activists organized a national strike_] [_seeking an eight-hour workday_]\n> \n> \n>",
      "score": 0.03157401,
      "raw_content": null
    },

      "title": "weekday / holiday | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/weekday-holiday.3689011/",
      "content": "Several words/phrases are quite frequently used: workday, work day, weekday, business day\n\n#### kentix\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - U.S.\n\n #16\n\nI would just ask them, \"What time do you get up on days you have to work?\"  \n   \n That covers all possibilities, including if they work Saturday or Sunday.\n\n#### kentix\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nEnglish - U.S.\n\n #17 [...] And 'workday' is meaningless when one is retired and on vacation and thus more likely to visit a museum on a Thursday morning, when all working folk are at work. [...] This is very helpful. Thanks much\\_rice.\n\n#### JulianStuart\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nSonoma County CA\n\nEnglish (UK then US)\n\n #20\n\n> meijin said:\n>\n> But isn't that the same as \"What time do you get up on workdays/working days?\" Is \"days you have to work\" more natural than \"workdays\" or \"working days\"?\n>\n> Click to expand...\n\nYet agian, we find multiple ways of saying the same thing in English\n\n#### meijin\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nTokyo\n\nJapanese\n\n #21",

      "content": "1. Employees access the web front end to request and manage automated solutions. Tasks are submitted through the web interface with specific requirements and parameters.\n2. The Azure App Service website receives the user request from the front end and calls an API hosted in Container Apps. That API processes the incoming task and determines which specialized AI agents are needed. The task is broken down into component parts for multiple-agent coordination. [...] This solution uses custom-coded, specialized AI agents that collaborate to break down complex organizational tasks into manageable components. Each agent contributes domain-specific knowledge and capabilities. This approach enables the system to manage sophisticated workflows that would otherwise require human coordination across multiple departments. The architecture scales through containerized deployment, preserves learning via persistent data storage, and supports continuous improvement [...] This architecture shows a process automation system that uses multiple AI agents. The agents are deployed into Azure Container Apps and use Azure AI services. This architecture's agents and orchestration behavior are defined in custom software with Microsoft Agent Framework.
